text: thanks everybody thanks for having us i think as michael said i wanted to reiterate one thing that
michael said that you know we're going to talk a lot about tinkering and the work that we do at the exploratorium around tinkering
we are not here to propose that you throw out everything that you've ever learned or every way that you ever learned as a student or as a as a
learner but we're trying to provide some alternative and some complementary facet to the spectrum of experiences that you
might get as a student over your lifetime through lecture through hands-on activities through demonstrations
the the question for us is what are we missing if we don't have a chance or many opportunities in our lifetime to
engage firsthand with science phenomenon art related processes and tools
materials and other stuff and so really that's what we have to share a little bit about today with you

are they're so connected and we really believe in this idea of constructionism that people think
differently when you're you're in the act of actively making something
so a lot of what we have to offer really does deal with physical stuff but i know
i know kind of a little bit about the world that you're in i spent a lot of time at the media lab in the lifelong
kindergarten group so a lot of times i'm going to be talking physical but i think a lot of those
ideas actually apply in the digital realm too um yeah
i'm going to read from this oh yeah here's a great quote so that these two things yeah tinkering

to get somewhere probably to have some dead ends along the way follow some strange tangents but this ability it's a

so for us the things that both at maker faire i mean maker faire open make and in the tinkering studio we look for
and sometimes get it wrong i mean a lot of things that we offer you know they they're not without their problems but
um if you took this venn diagram and did art science and technology we think that sweet spot in the middle where you
almost couldn't decide is this art is the science is that is this technology we like those things the most and try to
to capitalize on those and have more of those kinds of experiences offered
so but we also don't design these things for kids i mean there are a lot of kids that enjoy and and work with these
projects with us but we're this is not a kid-based endeavor in terms of our design so what i thought we would do is
talk a little bit about the design principles that we have and then how that maps on to some of the learning
outcomes that we're looking for so in the activities that you saw and the other activities that we do we uh we
break down our design principles into three categories the first is the activity design itself what are the
tools and the materials that we bring to this endeavor and what are the goals that we have in terms of meeting people
where they come in with their knowledge and what's the scientific content that we're hoping that they they walk away with or the scientific process skills we
also choose materials that are inviting or engaging in some immediate way and actually continue to work in that way as
you complexify your ideas and what's most important for us is that we're not trying to bring everybody in
and give them the quickest step-by-step resolution to what they don't know by
saying this is the best explanation for you we're trying to provide multiple pathways in and through these
explorations so that three different people might explore the activity in slightly different ways based on what
they come in thinking about their experience in that moment with other people and then what they might bring to it next time and i would just
want to point out this one the stem is a means not an end i mean a lot of people come to us for professional development
work and their goal is to do stem work in their classroom we feel like tinkering is a way to get
you there but it's it really truly is about the means and not like stem as the
goal so facilitation is another category that we carefully pay attention to all of the
activities that we have in the tinkering studio on the museum floor are facilitated by ourselves or explainers
these are teenage and college age students who come in and they get a lot of training from us and they're the facilitators
they're the people who are guiding and helping people through these explorations some of the things that we pay attention
to as we're designing activities is in terms of facilitation how do we welcome people and what's the initial
spark that might get people interested in doing something once they've started working on a project how do we sustain them you know
we were talking about getting people going and sometimes it can be really frustrating if you don't
know what your next step is going to be so we help people through that next step oftentimes you might you might you know
you might figure out how to hook up a wire and a battery in a bulb in an unexpected way that happened by accident
and so then as a facilitator we can step and kind of check your knowledge to make sure that if it was an accident there
are other opportunities and other materials that we can offer to help that and then finally
the environment it's an important one for us and here this is again where it's kind of physical digital or very connected to me but what what can you do
in an environment that makes people comfortable makes people comfortable with coming in and not necessarily knowing so how can
you um can the environment be shaped so tentative ideas can be tried out i mean
i i don't um well yeah okay i won't go down that path i'll say something about this later but i also feel like this
ways for you to come into a social space whether it's online or in the museum that would allow for cross-fertilization
of ideas also is another kind of interesting territory to be in and i think that environment
goes a long way you know there are just a couple of us for 30 or 50 people so two facilitators are not going to be
able to spend the entire 40 or 50 minutes with each individual learner so how do we create an environment in such a way where people are situated around
the work tables and start facilitating each other as they develop new ideas or as they make new insights so trying to
figure out what that environment is that sort of encourages this collective sharing of ideas through the process and
what can i say just one more thing i think also having an opportunity for people to feel like they do have a sense
of autonomy and they're kind of working on their idea but they're also participating in something larger than themselves i think is
good so then um the design principles go so far in terms of our goals for the
activity but the question for our team is also what are our goals about education what are the educational outcomes that we hope to get to and so
we've we've spent some time talking about this we broke them down into four four big ideas
first of all how do we think about getting people engaged in these things sometimes they come in with a proclivity
to start working on a project and sometimes we have to have the hundred thousand toothpick sculpture that scott weaver's
been working on for 37 years it's so outlandish that people become engaged just because of that fact
what is it through the activity where we can support learners to take their own initiative and build and construct with
real intentionality how do we develop like we were just discussing that social scaffold within
the environment so that people can actually support one another and finally even though ninety percent of of schools
and curriculum are focused on development of understanding for the content or more this word right yes
understanding we're not leaving it out we do have a goal that people are going to understand
more about circuits or light and color and sound or mechanics when they leave but it's just part of the overall set of
learning dimensions that we have so this is interesting because when
you are learning how to develop a curriculum usually the thing you start with is just number four there what are
your learning goals what are the things that someone can leave being able to state or accomplish and
the top three feel to me much more like the kinds of things that you would uh associate with many other kinds of
activities and i'm wondering is this is this something you brought to the
table is this something that you that you're drawing together like sort of more of the
museum kind of perspective here well it feels to me like so the design principles were sort of as we're
developing something to try out on the floor we try to hit a lot of those things and when people are engaged in
one of those activities we we came up with ways of describing kind of
the behaviors we were looking for and that's where the learning dimensions comes in and i think with each one of
these we'll see some in a minute but i think each one of those to us
was our end goal you'll kind of you'll kind of see more along each one of those but i think
the words development of understanding was also really critical because
getting straight to that content goal is not necessarily our
our end goal and i don't think anybody can truly develop an understanding or change their knowing about something
without a social endeavor of some sort without intentionally practicing and
exploring this work for themselves or becoming personally engaged in that process however if you never get here if
you never develop an understanding about this content that we're wanting to offer i mean we can we can engage and
entertain people until we're blue in the face but if it doesn't get to the point where you're actually complexifying in
your ideas and shifting your understanding about something it's an activity that doesn't have as much meaning for us as one that actually hits
all of these things so then what are the indicators for us
as we're facilitating and designing these spaces what is it about each of those four
learning dimensions that when visitors are with us indicate that something interesting and important is happening
and so we'll break it down just a little bit for each one
um yeah so well mike was just saying the spending time i mean that's definitely part of it but that's
we want more than that you know it's great that people want to spend time in the tinkering studio but if you follow
kind of engagement down to the next level we also believe that another uh indicator of that is really showing
motivation and interest and what does that look like so it looks like not sure what that emotion is that's
going on there but definitely motivated sometimes it's
kind of joy and pride and you'll hear it in what people say but it's a connection or kind of a reason that they're
compelled to kind of keep going with their investigation but again being personally engaged in this is really
important because very quickly if you're pushing on your thinking you might become frustrated at the
fuzziness that you're moving into an example might be if you come in and start working with circuit boards with
us and you're connecting batteries to bulbs using wires you might get that pretty quickly but
when i enter a new idea and ask you to you know integrate a switch or to make three
light bulbs turn on instead of just one that becomes a little bit of a challenge and i think pushes against some people's
understanding if you're not truly engaged and interested in solving that problem i think it's really hard to push
your ideas to that next level and then the initiative and
intentionality we kind of this is kind of still going in kind of a hierarchy of things we want
people to come into the space and be able to set their own goals not necessarily have that coming from us and you know
this is a great example she was working with stone circuits to create this bracelet and had some
working knowledge of circuits in the beginning but by the time she left it was a much deeper and um yeah she was
quite proud this is another sort of uh idea about
intentionality and persisting in this problem space one of the things that we try to do is offer complex challenges or
complex activities that actually force you to want to persist in building through that that um that moment
so scott weaver is a fellow has been working for 35 years in his living room constructing a city of san francisco out
of toothpicks and we've had it at the exploratorium for the last couple of years and the interesting thing to us is
for us this piece looks done i mean after 35 years and 100 000 toothpicks you'd think that this piece is finished
he comes in every other week to interact with the public but has been spending more and more time lately with his back
to the public continuing to work on his piece so what is it about the compelling
and sort of in the engagement level that we can design into these activities that allow people of all ages and backgrounds
to be okay at this point sort of tongue-in-cheek i mean we do want opportunities that allow people to
pursue persist in the problem space but um i think for us with scott the cool thing
about it for me is we get to offer a platform for him to come and share his work i met him walking across the
parking lot at a grocery store near my house he's the produce manager there he was wearing a toothpick hat
i mean i definitely my my radar is tuned now i look for makers and tinkerers all the time but um you know we struck up a
conversation and come to find out he had this nine foot by nine foot sculpture that he called rolling through the bay
it's an homage to san francisco but it's more than just a toothpick sculpture there are seven different runs
that you can stick a ping-pong ball down and it takes a tour of san francisco and
it'll take you through different areas of san francisco anyway i absolutely love that it's there at the museum
offers him a place to share his work and for other people to appreciate it and i also as mike was saying he literally is
still going he built this whole thing for the 49ers and when we lost he didn't put it on but he just added sutra towers
just last weekend a couple of other things another thing about the intentionality
you know again these are the indicators these are what people are saying and doing when we're noticing that these
activities are working for us and so one of the things that we often try to figure out is how can we support people
to take intellectual risks it's not so easy for young people but especially difficult for adults to be comfortable
not knowing something so what is it about the environment or our facilitation or the activity itself that
allows people to take an intellectual risk to go someplace where they're not comfortable going because as an adult
you're supposed to know the answers but the other thing that we do is we sort of parallel that with
risk taking in terms of mess in danger and using real tools and real materials you know this is a portable spot welder
that we're using to solder together lengths of wire on the museum floor this had never been done before at the
exploratorium we had to get more permits than you can imagine but it was worth it because we had young men and women
coming in and spot welding alongside parents who actually showed up that day because their job is as a spot welder
and they wanted to share that experience with each other the other fascinating thing about taking intellectual and even personal risks
with some of these things is that we don't shy away from danger we use hot glue guns and sharp knives
and lots of lots of power tools on the floor in safe ways but we want to get people
their first encounter sometimes with these tools in an environment that's purposeful and supported and it's
fascinating to watch how much more careful kids are with real tools in real danger than even adults or some of us
are at times but the intellectual risks that mike is talking about are kind of showing intellectual courage it's the
kind of thing we mean is when you're when you're working around a table and somebody sort of asserts an idea that is
in disagreement with someone next to them you know having that confidence to say no i don't really think that's the way that works it's it's that kind of
thing uh social scaffolding the museum is a
social space the tinkering studio is a social space on steroids you work really close uh to each other this example on
the right is marble machines and it's it's basically pegboard from home depot and stuff you can get molding and pipes
and tube and stuff like that and you're just building kind of runs for marbles the thing i love about it is
lots of people crowd around and work on this thing and often end up working with people that they didn't come into the museum with that's not something we see
in other parts of the museum so i find it really interesting and they're also not afraid to sort of look at something
that's not working even stating it out loud and then someone will quickly come over and join in their investigation
right along with them we spend a lot of time thinking about environments and also activities that
support the social scaffolding so when we when we see visitors who didn't come in together actually sharing ideas and
helping each other out it's a really important moment that we look at and try to figure out what's going on here
sometimes we're very purposeful with the activity you saw the the marble runs is one way where you can enter an environment and everybody's building
marble runs this is an activity that we're trying right now called light play it's a slow moving motor and some interesting leds
that actually creates light and shadow kinetic sculptures on these small portable screens so small groups you
know two three at a time will come in and construct little light play vignettes and this is all about geometry
of light and shadows and the distance between the light source and the shadow maker and the screen
but it's also it's an evocative and sort of beautiful outcome that you end up building when you're finished
but you're not taking it home many of the things that we build you're not taking home you're actually leaving behind for other visitors to come in and
start working on after you or in this case all of the individual screens are placed into a large cabinet in the back
so behind that that um the child and the woman there are 15
spaces for different light vignettes for you to actually contribute your contraption to the rest of the museum in
that way and then let new people come in to take a look at what's been done before you and maybe get some ideas about what what to happen next
uh and here's more about the development of understanding to us it um learning isn't linear and it's not
terminal you don't get to this point and you're like okay i know this now um we often see a lot of kind of
development happening when people are going to talk about or express a realization through affect or
utterances and what we mean by that is kind of you'll you'll see somebody working in there like oh i get it that's
connected you know what it you'll you'll hear it you you see it too in their body language that's kind of
the initial development of understanding and we
we really we try to either highlight mention those in passing kind of get other people
kind of into those investigations together by what the folks are saying and some of the under indicators the other thing that we see visitors doing a
lot is sharing explanations with each other persisting in that trouble space becoming frustrated but actually pushing
through it because they just really want to understand or as i mentioned before really trying to figure out how we can help people
apply what they've just explored to some new situation so i can complexify their
project by adding a new element or component or i might show that somebody next to them is working on a more
complex idea and ask them to work together a little bit people are very willing to do that to actually try to
figure out if they can take something that they think they understand and apply it to a slightly different situation can i tell them what that is
yeah so we we have one activity that's kind of on the other side of the space going on
when this when this is happening which i wish you could really really see to truly appreciate what's going on but
it's an activity called circuit board so it's basic kind of you would go to radio shack pull or digikey pull these things
off of the shelf put them in the table in front of you and start hooking things up there's no kind of set instructions
or step-by-step direction it's really kind of what part interests you and can you figure it out and we've done a lot
of activities where it's toy dissection you know like the elmo doll with that kid like how do you take apart a mechanical toy to the point where it
still works but you've got it in as many pieces as possible a real purposeful dissection activity so what i love about
this one we have these adult nights now so every thursday we're open from 6 to 10 for adults only and the first one of
the month we kind of do these blowout events february's was sexplorations you
know it's valentine's time so um what is happening here is a local store good
vibrations donated some equipment and this young lady with the purple hair
on the right is talking about some experience that she's had with this equipment and it has to do
directly with the circuit boards so they're talking about reasons for motors that are strong vibrations that are more
noticeable and less noticeable i mean i was turning every shade of red i was totally embarrassed throughout this this
uh investigation but it was one of those incredible moments like she was really applying direct experience with her
experience there on the floor of the museum we don't do sex toy dissections every night but when we can
um then there's just one sort of summary statement and this comes from a a colleague and mentor to us paul tatter
who um if there's there's anything that we're really trying to say here through all the design focus and the learning
indicators it's it's something like this i mean suppose that we assume that the purpose of learning and education is not just to remember a lot of things or to
provide a product that's what a lot of the maker movement is about this building this step-by-step product
but rather if education is about changing one's life and people changing their lives meanings that they're changing their relationships with each
other the things that they're interacting with and with their understanding of who they are themselves
if learning has to do with the meanings of things and i think this has allowed a lot to do with design and thinking about
interface if learning has to do with the meanings of things and those meanings have to do with the uses of those things
in our lives well then the meaning is in the use use these
you want to talk about this yeah so if something connected that we were saying with you and kind of resonated

and we have to back up and say are we being
as effective as educators and engaging people in conversation with
materials at that scale and i'm wondering if you have any thoughts

so are there ways to scale this is it just through volunteers what do you do here no not through

um the high touch point is definitely a part of it we it takes time
and it takes people working through this stuff but i think i think there is a way that you
can scale it up in terms of kind of it's almost like a grassroots enthusiasm
that's building and i think is a combination i think it's going to be a combination of kind of volunteer time
that might come in the form of parents you know kind of social groups hacker spaces clubs things like that nannies we
actually have nannies that are coming to the tinkering studio as a group they call it nanny camp and they're they're
coming together to spend some time in this place but i think what what it's
really doing it's it's tapping into personal interest and trying to connect folks in a way either whether it's kind
of who they are and what they do in their professional world or how they like to spend their time
you know outside of that work and so i mean i would i would echo that same sentiment i think this is about a distributed idea that first of all we
didn't invent we didn't start this this has been happening for eons and multiple cultures
and multiple parts of the world i think what we're doing is through the exploratorium is we're saying we think this is important and we're giving some
form to how that might happen in a museum with the hopes that we don't have to go to every museum to make it happen
but other educators other artists and other makers will actually take this on and start their own grassroots effort in
their community centers or at their schools or at their homes and so their kitchen table i mean i want to see tinkering studios everywhere not it's
it's a it's an approach as much as it is a physical space we'd rather see a thousand small groups work on this than
work with a thousand people in one space at one time
